metadata.titleEn: Long-term series of daily snow depth in Euroasia (1980-2016)
metadata.description:
The “long-term series of daily snow depth in Eurasia” was produced using the passive microwave remote sensing data. The temporal range is 1980~2016, and the coverage is the Eurasia continent. The spatial resolutions is 0.25° and the temporal resolution is daily. A dynamic brightness temperature gradient algorithm was used to derive snow depth. In this algorithm, the spatial and temporal variations of snow characteristics were considered and the spatial and seasonal dynamic relationships between the temperature difference between 18 GHz and 36 GHz and the measured snow depth were established. The long-term sequence of satellite-borne passive microwave brightness temperature data used to derive snow depth came from three sensors (SMMR, SSM/I and SSMI/S), and there is a certain system inconsistency among them. So, the inter-sensor calibration was performed to improve the temporal consistency of these brightness temperature data before snow depth derivation. The accuracy analysis shows that the relative deviation of Eurasia snow depth data is within 30%. The data are stored as a txt file every day, each file includes a file header (projection mode) and a 720*332 snow depth matrix, and each snow depth represents a 0.25°*0.25° grid.
For details of the data, please refer to data specification “Snow depth dataset of Eurasian (Version 1.0) (1980-2016).doc”

background: Seasonal snow cover plays an important role in hydrological cycles and climate processes. Snow depth is a significant parameter in climate and hydrologic model simulations. At present, passive microwave remote sensing is the most efficient way to derive snow depth at global and regional scales. The current snow depth or SWE retrieval algorithms have been developed based on the fact that deeper snowpacks have lower microwave brightness temperatures and that the brightness temperature difference (TBD) at 18 GHz and 36 GHz increases with increasing snow depth. But when the snow depth reaches up to a certain threshold, the brightness temperature at 36 GHz begins to increase slowly or keep stable with the increase of snow depth due to the fact that snow depth exceeds the penetration depth of the 36 GHz, resulting in the TBD at 18 GHz and 36 GHz decreases with the increase of snow depth. Therefore, when snow depth is more than this threshold, the lower frequencies (such as 10 GHz and 18 GHz) can be used to retrieve snow depth/SWE.
research objective: A novel snow depth/water equivalent (SWE) data retrieval algorithm from passive microwave brightness temperature is proposed based on a priori snow characteristics, including the grain size, density, and temperature of the layered snowpack. In this paper, a snow depth/SWE retrieval algorithm of a look-up table was developed based on a priori snow characteristics (stratigraphy, snow grain size, density, snow temperature, and temperature at the snow/soil interface) in Xinjiang, China.
challenges: Static snow depth retrieval algorithms tend to underestimate the snow depth at the beginning of the snow season and overestimate the snow depth at the end of the snow season because the snow characteristics vary with the age of snow cover. The observations of the sparse weather stations are not sufficient for this purpose; therefore, it is important to develop a snow depth or snow water equivalent (SWE) retrieval method from remote sensing data. However, it becomes more difficult to retrieve the snow depth and SWE of a layered snowpack from brightness temperature data because the layered condition is unknown.
methods: The snow depth and SWE determined by this new algorithm were validated by snow measurements at thirteen meteorological stations in Xinjiang, China from 2003 to 2010 and compared with existing SWE products from the National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC), the Environmental and Ecological Science Data Center for West China (WESTDC), the European Space Agency (ESA), and measurements with a snow course. We used the Advanced Microwave Scanning Radiometer for Earth Observing System (AMSR-E) data in this study. In this study, we propose a look-up table method to retrieve snow depth and SWE. First, a look-up table between snow properties and passive microwave brightness temperature at AMSR-E frequencies was established using the microwave emission model of layered snowpacks (MEMLS) based on a priori snow characteristics, which come from field measurements and meteorological station data.
dataset: The snow depth and SWE determined by this new algorithm were validated by snow measurements at thirteen meteorological stations in Xinjiang, China from 2003 to 2010. We used the Advanced Microwave Scanning Radiometer for Earth Observing System (AMSR-E) data in this study. The daily snow depth, snow pressure, and minimum air temperature observations from 55 stations in Xinjiang, China, from 1999 to 2008 (several up to 2010) are available from the China Meteorological Administration. From November of 2010 to March of 2011, three field measurements were established in Northern Xinjiang, and at the end of February of 2011, snow depths were measured along a snow course.
findings: The results showed that the root mean squared error (RMSE) and the bias from this new algorithm were greatly reduced compared to NSIDC, moderately reduced compared to ESA, and slightly reduced compared to WESTDC. The understanding of a priori local snow characteristics can improve the accuracy of snow depth and snow water equivalent estimation from passive microwave remote sensing data.

Verification.Question: Can passive microwave remote sensing be used to efficiently derive snow depth on a global scale?
Do static snow depth retrieval algorithms underestimate snow depth at the beginning of the snow season?

Disjunctive.Question: Is snow depth retrieval from passive microwave remote sensing more efficient using dynamic brightness temperature gradient algorithms or static retrieval algorithms?
Are field measurements or meteorological station data more critical for validating snow depth and SWE retrieval algorithms?
Disjunctive.Answer: Field measurements and meteorological station data are both critical for validating snow depth and SWE retrieval algorithms as they provide essential a priori snow characteristics and ground truth for validation.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to ensure temporal consistency across different passive microwave sensors for snow depth measurement?
Example.Answer: To ensure temporal consistency across different passive microwave sensors like SMMR, SSM/I, and SSMI/S, a cross-correction of brightness temperatures from these sensors was performed before snow depth extraction.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in developing snow depth retrieval methods from passive microwave data, and how is it addressed?
Example.Answer: A challenge in developing snow depth retrieval methods is the underestimation or overestimation of snow depth due to changing snow characteristics over time. This is addressed by proposing a snow depth retrieval algorithm that considers a priori snow characteristics such as grain size, density, and temperature, validated through field measurements and meteorological data.

Example.Question: Can you illustrate an example of how snow depth datasets are validated using field measurements?
Example.Answer: Snow depth datasets are validated by comparing the snow depth and SWE determined by a new retrieval algorithm with snow measurements at thirteen meteorological stations in Xinjiang, China, from 2003 to 2010, and comparing these with existing SWE products from organizations like NSIDC and ESA.

Definition.Question: What is the 'dynamic brightness temperature gradient algorithm' used in passive microwave remote sensing for snow depth retrieval?
Definition.Answer: The dynamic brightness temperature gradient algorithm is a method that takes into account the spatial and temporal variations of snow characteristics by establishing a dynamic relationship between brightness temperature differences at multiple frequencies and actual snow depth. It is used to retrieve snow depth from passive microwave remote sensing data.

Definition.Question: What does 'cross-calibration of brightness temperatures across different sensors' entail in the context of snow depth data extraction?
Definition.Answer: Cross-calibration of brightness temperatures across different sensors involves ensuring the consistency of brightness temperature measurements over time by correcting for any discrepancies between sensors. This is crucial for accurate snow depth extraction from data collected by different sensors such as SMMR, SSM/I, and SSMI/S to ensure temporal consistency.

Comparison.Question: How does the integration of data from multiple sensors like SMMR, SSM/I, and SSMI/S affect the consistency of snow depth datasets compared to using data from a single sensor?
Comparison.Answer: Integrating data from multiple sensors, such as SMMR, SSM/I, and SSMI/S, necessitates cross-calibration to ensure temporal consistency in brightness temperatures, which can lead to more reliable long-term datasets. Using data from a single sensor may avoid cross-calibration issues but could limit the temporal span and potentially miss improvements in later sensor technologies.

Interpretation.Question: How might the dynamic brightness temperature gradient algorithm address the challenges of accurately retrieving snow depth in regions with complex snowpack structures?
Interpretation.Answer: The dynamic brightness temperature gradient algorithm considers the spatiotemporal variability of snow characteristics to improve the accuracy of snow depth retrieval. It establishes a dynamic relationship between brightness temperature differences and measured snow depth across different frequencies and seasons, which can address the underestimation and overestimation issues by accounting for changes in snow properties over time.

Interpretation.Question: What could be the implications of using multiple sensors like SMMR, SSM/I, and SSMI/S for ensuring consistency in long-term snow depth datasets?
Interpretation.Answer: Using multiple sensors like SMMR, SSM/I, and SSMI/S requires cross-correction of brightness temperatures to ensure temporal consistency. This approach helps in maintaining uniformity in datasets collected over long periods, thus reducing relative biases in snow depth measurements to within 30% and enabling reliable long-term studies of snow cover and climate interactions.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways might a priori knowledge of snow characteristics enhance the development of retrieval algorithms for snow depth and snow water equivalent (SWE)?
Interpretation.Answer: A priori knowledge of snow characteristics, such as grain size, density, and temperature, can significantly enhance retrieval algorithms by providing essential input data that account for variations in snowpack properties. This knowledge allows for the development of look-up tables and models that can more accurately predict snow depth and SWE, especially when dealing with layered snowpacks where direct measurements are challenging.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the variability in accuracy when using passive microwave remote sensing to derive snow depth across different seasons?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Static snow depth retrieval algorithms tend to underestimate snow depth at the beginning of the snow season and overestimate it at the end due to variations in snow characteristics with the age of the snow cover.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the complexity of retrieving snow depth and snow water equivalent from brightness temperature data in layered snowpack conditions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The difficulty arises because the layered condition of the snowpack is unknown, making it challenging to accurately retrieve snow depth and SWE from brightness temperature data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it necessary to perform cross-correction of brightness temperature data from different sensors before extracting snow depth?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Cross-correction ensures temporal consistency in brightness temperature data across different sensors, which is crucial for accurate snow depth extraction.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the effects of utilizing passive microwave remote sensing data on the accuracy of snow depth estimates over a long temporal scale?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of passive microwave remote sensing data, such as from SMMR, SSM/I, and SSMI/S sensors, allows for the creation of long-term snow depth datasets. The dynamic brightness temperature algorithm helps to account for temporal and spatial variations in snow characteristics, resulting in snow depth data with a relative bias within 30% when validated against ground measurements.

Causal Consequence.Question: What potential challenges arise from the dynamic nature of snow characteristics in developing accurate snow depth retrieval algorithms?
Causal Consequence.Answer: One challenge is that static snow depth retrieval algorithms may underestimate snow depth at the beginning of the snow season and overestimate it at the end due to variations in snow characteristics as the snow cover ages. This necessitates the development of algorithms that can dynamically adjust to these changes.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of cross-calibrating brightness temperatures from different sensors on the consistency of snow depth data extraction?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Cross-calibrating brightness temperatures from multiple sensors ensures temporal consistency in the snow depth data extracted. This calibration is crucial for maintaining accuracy across the long time series data from 1980 to 2016.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary goal of using passive microwave remote sensing techniques in the development of long-term snow depth datasets across large geographical regions like Eurasia?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary goal is to efficiently derive snow depth at global and regional scales, as passive microwave remote sensing is the most effective method for this purpose. This approach helps in understanding seasonal snow cover's role in hydrological cycles and climate processes.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to validate snow depth retrieval algorithms with in-situ measurements and compare them with existing snow products from various data centers?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important to validate snow depth retrieval algorithms with in-situ measurements and compare them with existing products to improve accuracy and ensure that the algorithms can reliably estimate snow depth and snow water equivalent, especially when dealing with layered snowpacks where conditions are unknown.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives behind using a look-up table method based on a priori snow characteristics in the retrieval of snow depth and snow water equivalent?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objectives include improving the estimation accuracy of snow depth and snow water equivalent from passive microwave remote sensing data by incorporating local snow characteristics like stratigraphy, grain size, density, and temperature into the retrieval process.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are used to ensure the temporal consistency of brightness temperature data from different sensors before extracting snow depth data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To ensure temporal consistency of brightness temperature data from different sensors, cross-correction is performed on the brightness temperatures before snow depth extraction.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can passive microwave remote sensing be adapted to improve snow depth retrieval in regions with varying snowpack characteristics?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Passive microwave remote sensing can be adapted by using a dynamic brightness temperature gradient algorithm that accounts for spatiotemporal variations in snow characteristics, establishing a dynamic relationship between brightness temperature differences and measured snow depth across different frequencies.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What steps are involved in creating a look-up table to retrieve snow depth and snow water equivalent from passive microwave brightness temperature data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Creating a look-up table involves using the microwave emission model of layered snowpacks (MEMLS) based on a priori snow characteristics from field measurements and meteorological station data to establish a relationship between snow properties and passive microwave brightness temperature at specific frequencies.

Enablement.Question: What conditions and technological advancements enable the extraction of snow depth data from passive microwave remote sensing across large geographical areas like Eurasia?
Enablement.Answer: The use of dynamic brightness temperature gradient algorithms, which account for spatial and temporal variations in snow characteristics, enables the extraction of snow depth data from passive microwave remote sensing across large areas. Additionally, advancements in satellite sensors like SMMR, SSM/I, and SSMI/S, and the cross-correction of their brightness temperatures for consistency over time, are crucial technological enablers.

Enablement.Question: How do variations in snow characteristics across seasons and regions influence the development of algorithms for snow depth retrieval from satellite data?
Enablement.Answer: Variations in snow characteristics such as grain size, density, and temperature influence the development of retrieval algorithms by necessitating dynamic models that adjust for changes in snowpack properties over time and space. These variations can lead to underestimations or overestimations of snow depth if not properly accounted for in the algorithm design.

Expectation.Question: Why might static snow depth retrieval algorithms underestimate or overestimate snow depth at different times of the snow season?
Expectation.Answer: Static snow depth retrieval algorithms tend to underestimate snow depth at the beginning of the snow season and overestimate it at the end due to variations in snow characteristics with the age of the snow cover.

Expectation.Question: What factors could contribute to the high relative deviation observed in snow depth data across the Eurasian continent?
Expectation.Answer: The high relative deviation in snow depth data could be due to the dynamic nature of snow characteristics over time and space, which are considered in the retrieval algorithm to account for changes in snow properties.

Expectation.Question: Why is it challenging to retrieve snow depth and SWE from brightness temperature data in a layered snowpack?
Expectation.Answer: Retrieving snow depth and SWE from brightness temperature data in a layered snowpack is challenging because the layered condition is unknown, making it difficult to accurately assess and model the snow properties.

Judgmental.Question: How effective do you think the passive microwave remote sensing method is in addressing the challenges of retrieving snow depth across varying snowpack conditions and regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The passive microwave remote sensing method is considered the most efficient way to derive snow depth at global and regional scales. However, it faces challenges such as underestimating snow depth at the beginning of the snow season and overestimating it at the end, due to changes in snow characteristics with the age of snow cover. The method can become more difficult when retrieving snow depth and SWE of a layered snowpack since the layered condition is unknown.

Judgmental.Question: What is your perspective on the utility of integrating field measurements and meteorological station data to enhance the accuracy of snow depth and SWE retrieval algorithms?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating field measurements and meteorological station data with remote sensing data, like AMSR-E, can significantly enhance the accuracy of snow depth and SWE retrieval algorithms. This approach allows for the establishment of a look-up table method, improving the understanding of local snow characteristics and reducing errors compared to existing products from organizations like NSIDC and ESA.

Judgmental.Question: To what extent do you believe the temporal and spatial resolution of 0.25° and daily frequency are adequate for capturing the dynamics of snow depth across the Eurasian continent?
Judgmental.Answer: The temporal resolution of daily frequency and a spatial resolution of 0.25° are deemed adequate for capturing the dynamics of snow depth across the Eurasian continent. This setup allows for the observation of snow depth variations over a long time series (1980-2016), providing a comprehensive dataset for analyzing seasonal and regional snow cover changes using passive microwave remote sensing data.

Assertion.Question: I can't understand how passive microwave remote sensing can accurately estimate snow depth across varying snowpack conditions in different regions.
Assertion.Answer: Passive microwave remote sensing is effective for estimating snow depth because it utilizes the relationship between microwave brightness temperatures and snow characteristics. The brightness temperature difference at specific frequencies (18 GHz and 36 GHz) is used to infer snow depth, with adjustments for deeper snowpacks requiring lower frequencies like 10 GHz and 18 GHz when the snow exceeds certain penetration depths.

Assertion.Question: I'm not sure why static snow depth retrieval algorithms might not be accurate throughout the entire snow season.
Assertion.Answer: Static snow depth retrieval algorithms may not be accurate throughout the snow season because they don't account for changes in snow characteristics over time. Snow properties such as grain size, density, and temperature can vary as the snow cover ages, leading to underestimations at the beginning and overestimations at the end of the snow season.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the methodological approach used for deriving long-term snow depth datasets using passive microwave remote sensing on the Eurasian continent.
Request/Directive.Answer: The long-term snow depth dataset for the Eurasian continent was developed using a dynamic brightness temperature gradient algorithm applied to passive microwave remote sensing data. This algorithm considers the spatial and temporal variation of snow characteristics, using a dynamic relationship between brightness temperature differences at multiple frequencies and measured snow depth. The data was derived from brightness temperature data collected by SMMR, SSM/I, and SSMI/S sensors from 1980 to 2016, with cross-calibration performed to ensure consistency across different sensors.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in retrieving snow depth using static algorithms and how they might affect data accuracy.
Request/Directive.Answer: Static snow depth retrieval algorithms often underestimate snow depth at the beginning of the snow season and overestimate it at the end due to the variability in snow characteristics over time. These algorithms do not account for the changes in snowpack stratigraphy, grain size, density, and temperature as snow ages. This results in inaccuracies, as these static methods cannot adapt to the dynamic nature of snow cover. Additionally, sparse weather station data exacerbates this issue, highlighting the need for a more responsive retrieval method from remote sensing data.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the potential improvements in snow depth estimation accuracy when using a priori local snow characteristics combined with passive microwave remote sensing data.
Request/Directive.Answer: Using a priori local snow characteristics, such as snow stratigraphy, grain size, density, and temperatures, significantly improves the accuracy of snow depth and snow water equivalent estimations from passive microwave remote sensing data. This approach involves the use of a look-up table method that correlates snow properties with brightness temperatures, validated against field measurements. The use of AMSR-E data and validation against ground measurements demonstrated reduced RMSE and bias, highlighting the benefit of incorporating local snow characteristics for more precise snow depth retrieval.
